sen.j: 保津峡（ほづきょう）は、京都府亀岡市から京都市右京区嵐山の渡月橋に至る大堰川（保津川）の景勝地。
sen.e: The Hozukyo Gorge is a picturesque scenic spot on the Oi-gawa river (the Hozu River) starting from Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture, and running through to Togetsu-kyo Bridge in Arashiyama, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.

The Hozukyo Gorge is a picturesque scenic spot on the Oi-gawa river (the Hozu River) starting from Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture, and running through to Togetsu-kyo Bridge in Arashiyama, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The Hozukyo Gorge, a picturesque scenic spot on the Oi-gawa River (the Hozu-gawa River), starts at Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture to Togetsu-kyo Bridge in Arashiyama, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。-ku削除the Oi-gawa river→the Oi-gawa River

sen.j: 保津川は渡月橋から桂川 (淀川水系)となる。
sen.e: The Hozu River changes its name to the Katsura river (the Yodo river system) at the Togetsu-kyo Bridge.
The Hozu River becomes the Katsura river (the Yodo river system) at the Togetsu-kyo Bridge.
sen.cmt: wording
sen.e: The Hozu-gawa River ends at the Togetsu-kyo Bridge where it flows into the Katsura-gawa River (the Yodo-gawa river system).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。the Katsura-gawa river→the Katsura-gawa Fiver

sen.j: 府立保津峡自然公園に含まれる。
sen.e: The prefectural Hozukyo National Park includes the gorge.
The prefectural Hozukyo National Park includes the gorge.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Kyoto prefectural Hozukyo Natural Park includes the gorge.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 保津峡は江戸時代の1606年（慶長11年）に角倉了以が、丹波の産物を京都に運搬するために造った水路である。
sen.e: The Hozukyo Gorge is a waterway constructed by Ryoi SUMINOKURA in 1606, in the Edo period, to ship "Made in Tanba" products to Kyoto.
The Hozukyo Gorge is a waterway constructed by Ryoi SUMINOKURA in 1606, in the Edo period, to ship products from Tamba to Kyoto.
sen.cmt: wording
sen.e: The Hozukyo Gorge is a waterway constructed by Ryoi SUMINOKURA (1554-1614, wealthy merchant, shipowner, builder, and excavator) in 1606 in the Edo period to ship products from Tanba province (northwest of Kyoto) to Kyoto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。TanbaをTambaに変更しました。Tamba→Tanba

sen.j: 保津川は蛇行を繰り返す激流で大きな岩が無数にあったが、人力で引っ張ったり火薬を使って発破作業を行ったりしながら、高瀬舟の通れる水路を約5か月で完成させたという。
sen.e: It is said that although the Hozu River was a meandering, raging torrent and there were innumerable huge rocks in the river, the waterway was completed in five months by pulling rocks away by human strength and blasting them with gunpowder so that Takasebune boats were able to travel.

It is said that although the Hozu River was a meandering, raging torrent and there were innumerable huge rocks in the river, the waterway was completed in five months by manually removing rocks and blasting them with gunpowder so that Takasebune boats were able to navigate the waters.
sen.cmt: wording
sen.e: It is said that although the Hozu-gawa River was a meandering, raging torrent and there were innumerable huge rocks in the river, the waterway was completed in five months by manually removing rocks and blasting them with gunpowder so that Takasebune boats were able to navigate the waters.
sen.cmt: 用語表記を変えました。

sen.j: それ以後、保津川は丹波と京を結ぶ産業水路として発展した。
sen.e: Since then, the Hozu River has developed as an industrial waterway connecting Tanba with Kyoto.
Since then, the Hozu River has developed as an industrial waterway connecting Tamba with Kyoto.
sen.cmt: spelling
sen.e: Since then, the Hozu-gawa River has developed as an industrial waterway connecting Tanba with Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 用語表記を変えました。

sen.j: 近世になって主要な運搬物であった木材の需要が減り、同時に鉄道網が発達すると舟運の役目は終え水路は廃れた。
sen.e: In early-modern times, because the demand for lumber, which was the major freight, had dropped and a railway network developed at the same time, transportation by ship completed its role and the waterway became outdated.

In early-modern times, because the demand for lumber-- a major freight--had dropped and a railway network developed at the same time, transportation by ship completed its role and the waterway became outdated.
sen.cmt: wording
sen.e: In early-modern times, since the demand for lumber (major cargo) had dropped, while the railway network had been expanded, ship transportation completed its role and the waterway became obsolete.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

tit.cmt: 用語表記を変えました。

sen.j: 景勝地である嵯峨野・嵐山に近いことから観光化の道を進み、1885年（明治28年）に観光客を対象とした遊覧船による川下りが行われるようになった。
sen.e: Due to the gorge's being the neighbor of the picturesque scenery of Sagano and Arashiyama, developments for tourism proceeded and river trips for tourists using pleasure boats began in 1885.
Due to the gorge neighboring the picturesque scenery of Sagano and Arashiyama, developments for tourism proceeded and river trips for tourists using pleasure boats began in 1885.
sen.cmt: wording
sen.e: Since the gorge has the picturesque scenery of Sagano and Arashiyama in its neighbor, developments for tourism proceeded there and river trips for tourists using pleasure boats began in 1885.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この風流な保津川下りは夏目漱石の『虞美人草』を始め、水上勉、薄田泣菫、大町桂月、三島由紀夫など幾つもの文学作品に登場した。
sen.e: Elegant trips down to the Hozu river appeared in the literary works of Tsutomu MINAKAMI, Kyukin SUSUKIDA, Keigetsu OMACHI and Yukio MISHIMA, to say nothing of "Gubijinso" (The Poppy) written by Soseki NATSUME..

Elegant trips down to Hozu river appeared in the literary works of Tsutomu MINAKAMI, Kyukin SUSUKIDA, Keigetsu OMACHI and Yukio MISHIMA, to say nothing of Gubijinso (The Poppy) written by Soseki NATSUME..
sen.cmt: punctuation
sen.e: Elegant trips down the Hozu-gawa River appeared in the literary works of Tsutomu MINAKAMI, Kyukin SUSUKIDA, Keigetsu OMACHI and Yukio MISHIMA, let alone "Gubijinso (The Poppy) " written by Soseki NATSUME.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。重複していたピリオドを一つ取り除きました。作品名に""をつけました。the Hozu-gawa river→the Hozu-gawa River

sen.j: 当時は、京都から人力車にのって老の坂を越え、篠町王子を経て保津川の亀岡盆地から保津峡への入り口にあたる山本浜（現在のトロッコ亀岡駅辺り）から乗船した。
sen.e: In those days, people left Kyoto, crossed the Oi no saka Pass by a jinrikisha (a taxi-like vehicle pulled by a man), passed Shinochooji and the Hozu river at the Kameoka basin, and embarked on a boat at Yamamoto-hama (the neighborhood of the present Kameoka Torokko Station), which was the entrance to the Hozukyo Gorge.

sen.j: ルーマニア皇太子やイギリス皇太子などの賓客も興じたことから、王子から山本浜までの道のりは『京都府道402号王子並河線』と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Because honored guests such as the crown prince of Romania and the Prince of Wales also enjoyed this trip, the way from Oji to Yamamoto-hama was called "Kyoto prefectural road No.402, Oji Namikawa Route".

sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その後、川下りは大衆的なものとなり、また、乗船場もJR嵯峨野線亀岡駅近くに移された。
